description:
Leucopleurus acutus is a species of beetle belonging to the family Cerambycidae, commonly known as longhorn beetles. It is found in parts of North America, including the United States and Canada.

Leucopleurus acutus is a small to medium-sized beetle, typically measuring between 10-15 millimeters in length. The body is elongated and cylindrical in shape, with a distinct head and antennae. The antennae are long and slender, often exceeding the length of the body. The elytra (hardened forewings) are usually dark in color, often with a mottled or patterned appearance.

The species is known for its acute or pointed pronotum, which is the segment behind the head. This distinctive feature is where the species gets its scientific name, "acutus," meaning "sharp" or "pointed."

Leucopleurus acutus inhabits various types of forested environments, where the larvae feed on the wood of dead or dying trees. The adults are often found on the trunks or branches of these host plants, where they may be observed feeding on sap or pollen.

Like many longhorn beetles, Leucopleurus acutus plays an important role in the decomposition of woody plant material, contributing to the nutrient cycling within forest ecosystems.
